title: Whittlesey Heritage Walk Route

images.title: Michael Trolove / Butter Cross, Whittlesey
images.caption: Butter Cross, Whittlesey. A late 17th Century building used as an open market, threatened with demolition in its early life, now an attractive town centre feature. For a long time in the 20th century buses and cars vied for space around the structure. In 1999 Fenland District Council enhanced the area making it more pedestrian friendly.

images.title: Summertown Morris dancing on The Market - Whittlesea Straw Bear Festival 2014 by Richard Humphrey, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Summertown Morris dancing on The Market - - Whittlesea Straw Bear Festival 2014

images.title: Michael Trolove / Whittlesey Town Hall
images.caption: Whittlesey Town Hall. The town hall doubled as the fire engine house, the two arched doors either side of the main door have fire engine lettered around them. It now houses the town museum.

images.title: Michael Trolove / Unused building in Whittlesey market place
images.caption: Unused building in Whittlesey market place. Another building with sterling board windows. The George Hotel next door on the left has suffered the same fate.

images.title: Michael Trolove / The Black Bull Inn
images.caption: The Black Bull Inn. Next door to the old town hall in central Whittlesey.

images.title: Michael Trolove / Thatched building near the Butter Cross
images.caption: Thatched building near the Butter Cross. Moss ridden thatch on a building in Whittlesey Market place.

images.title: Thatched cottages by Briggate River, Whittlesey by Richard Humphrey, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Thatched cottages by Briggate River, Whittlesey

images.title: David P Howard / The Museum, Whittlesey
images.caption: The Museum

description: This circular walk takes you to a series of historical sites in the Cambridgshire town of Whittlesey. The ancient market town is a fascinating place for a walk with some splendid architecture, listed buildings, scheduled ancient monuments and old churches. At the southern end of the walk there's nice views of the Briggate River. The route links up with other trails that will take you to the nearby Lattersey Nature Reserve and King’s Dyke Nature Reserve. You can start and finish the walk at the historic market place where there is an information board with more details. To continue your walking in the town head north to pick up the Nene Way and enjoy a waterside walk along the River Nene. The long distance Hereward Way also passes through the town. https://www.fenland.gov.uk/media/19097/Whittlesey-Heritage-Walk-Brochure/pdf/WHW_Brochure_2.pdf?m=638053163792800000 https://www.fenland.gov.uk/WhittleseyHeritageWalk

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: The New Crown is a Grade II listed pub dating back to the 17th century. The ancient thatched pub includes a charming interior with wooden decor and beamed ceilings. They serve good home-cooked food and real ales. Accommodation is also available if you would like to stay over. You can find them at 58 High Causeway with postcode PE7 1QA for your sat navs. The inn is also dog friendly.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: If you head east you could visit the historic market town of March where there's attractive parks, Georgian buildings and a noteworthy riverside pub dating back to the 17th century. For cyclists National Cycle Route 63 passes through the town. The Peterborough To Whittlesey cycle route is a largely traffic free section which will take you into nearby Peterborough along the Nene River. It's suitable for walkers too.

display_address: Market Street, Whittlesey, Fenland, Cambridgeshire, Cambridgeshire and Peterborough, England, PE7 1BD, United Kingdom
